hobby.message: Origami help keep the noise out?
Urban exploration still your kind of therapy?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Still on my feet.
Just keeping up with repairs. Making time for my drone when I can.
Not much free space left outside these days.
Hobby's flying drones—mostly solo runs when it's quiet.
I made it. Barely found a spot to land my drone tonight.
Used to be simple—fly, unwind, solve for wind drag and line of sight.
Lately, the crowds and new signals mess with my routine.
Whole district runs on neighborhood orders now, harder to find quiet zones.
I still fly, just have to adapt.
I made it. Brought my FPV drone with me, actually—freestyle flying is what clears my head.
Usually run circuits in the industrial zone after my shift.
Recently, everyone’s out there—organizing or running stuff, blocking some airspace.
It’s changed my routes. Had to switch from tricks to helping relay signals.
Not the escape it used to be, but I still get a few clean flights in.
Honestly, it helps when things get too unpredictable.
I did. Fitting in a fly whenever I can, even when the city’s a mess.
Freestyle drone flying is my thing. Started years ago, keeps my mind quiet.
Last week at Oktyabrsky depot, whole place transformed—organized chaos, runners everywhere.
Got pulled in to help them fix their mesh net, used my drone as a relay.
It’s different—used to fly for myself, now it’s about patching people together.
I’ve missed the risky lines, but running comms has its kick.
Everyone’s found new uses for their old obsessions lately.
Yeah, made it—snuck out after a few hours of patching up the local mesh.
Freestyle FPV drone flying isn’t just a hobby, it’s the one thing I didn’t let the system automate.
Used to run laps for fun, experiment with acro mods, film abandoned spots before curfew.
Now? Since the network went peer-to-peer, everyone needs eyes in the sky—transponders, repeaters, mobile scouts.
Last weekend, I retooled my quad to boost the neighborhood net—blocked Council jammers, patched a medical runner’s signal through an old grain silo.
Never thought drone tricks would keep our block online.
Funny how hobbies turn into lifelines when the city slips off-grid.
I’d probably lose my head without those circuits and the empty sky.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still fly sometimes.
Less open space now with all these groups camping out.
Was almost grounded last time by new patrols.
Signals are weird with the networks up.
Safer to keep it short lately.
Yeah, still fly when I can.
Neighborhoods running their own networks now—cuts into my usual spots.
Had to dodge some new faces last flight.
A lot more interference than before.
People use drones for relays now.
Not always easy to just fly for fun.
Yeah, FPV is still my escape.
Routes have changed since the BCI slipped and local traffic spiked.
Last weekend, I had to patch my signal; too many encrypted nets crowding the band.
Some groups actually asked for help relaying their comms.
Flying's not as relaxing—less tricks, more problem-solving.
Feels like everyone's repurposing their toys these days.
But I get some air when I can.
Yeah, I keep at it whenever possible.
Flying used to be just my downtime—cleared my head after work.
Now, with everyone running peer-to-peer, my drone's more relay than racer.
Got roped in to boost local mesh for food drop-offs last week.
It's weird—used to fly alone; now, everyone's watching, needing something.
Neighborhood nets crowd the air, jammers flicker in and out.
Sometimes I miss when it was just about speed—no risks, no politics.
But I guess everyone adapts when systems break.
Definitely still fly, but it's not what it used to be.
Drones were my way out—brother even built my first frame.
After the BCI collapsed, I became the unofficial mesh-link for three blocks.
Patched relays to keep med supplies moving—my quad covers dead zones central systems ignore.
Jamming from Council teams makes the air unpredictable; almost lost a unit Saturday.
Sometimes, I wish I could just freestyle again without watching for who’s listening.
The new networks are fragile—one bad hop and half the block misses a delivery.
It’s the closest thing to freedom now, but it’s not simple fun anymore.
Maybe one day it’ll feel like just a hobby again.
